How I solved the equation (took me a while to understand)

122 m - 0m =0m*7s + 1/2a7s^2
122 m = 0m + 1/2*49 (because we're looking for a, and because 7 squared is 49)
Then you divide the fraction (numerator ÷ denominator)
1/ 2 = 0.5
And multiply 0.5 with 49
0.5*49= 24.5
And lastly, divide 122 through 24.5
122/24.5 = 4.9...
And round up to 5

Which is how you get to 5 m/s^2

Well. It's very interesting, but she moves so fast. Especially over the displacement curve (2nd kinematic equation) part. I'm an old guy and you need to slow down, young lady. But it's very interesting. I guess I'll have to watch it again!

Velocity

Velocity →v is a vector physical quantity that expresses a change of the position vector →r in a unit of time Δt.

In the SI system, the basic unit of velocity is ms. Velocity expressed in ms provides information about the number of meters travelled by an object in 1 second of motion.

If a specific direction can be assigned to the motion, then velocity is also a directed (vector) quantity. This means that velocity has:
- a direction - the same as the direction of motion
- a sense - identifies the side in which the velocity in the specific direction is orientated
- a value - the length of the velocity vector →v

Depending on the velocity, the following categories of motion are identified:
- uniform motion (constant velocity in time)
- non-uniform motion (velocity changing during the motion)

Average velocity

Average velocity →vavg defines the rate of change of the position vector Δ→r in time Δt not approaching zero.

It is defined as the ratio of displacement Δ→r to time Δt in which the displacement took place:

→vavg=Δ→rΔt
The direction of the average velocity vector is the same as the direction of the displacement vector.

￼
A material point at the initial moment t1=0 was in position A. After some time, at moment t2=t, it was in position B. The displacement of the point is:

Δ→r=→r2−→r1
The time in which the displacement took place is equal to:

Δt=t2−t1=t

Instantaneous velocity

Instantaneous velocity is the velocity of a body in a time interval approaching zero. This is why it is defined as the limit of the quotient of displacement Δ→r to time at Δt approaching 0:

→v=limt→0Δ→rΔt
Differential notation:→v=d→rdt
Unlike average velocity, instantaneous velocity detects sudden changes in the movement of a body. For example, the body did not move for 1 second. For another 1 second it moved over a distance of 2 meters. The average velocity during 2 seconds is equal to:

vavg=ΔrΔt=2m2s=1ms
Even though the body did not move in the initial phase of the measurement, its average velocity is not equal to zero. If the motion is considered in intervals approaching 0, the initial values of instantaneous velocity are equal to zero.

The direction of the instantaneous velocity vector of the body →v is the same as the direction of a tangent to the path of the body in the point where the body is located.

￼

Acceleration

Acceleration →a is a vector physical quantity that expresses the change of the velocity vector →v in a set interval Δt. Thus, it can be said that acceleration defines how fast the velocity of an object changes in time.

If a body moves with constant velocity v, its acceleration a is equal to 0, and the motion of the body is referred to as uniform.

In a straight-line motion, the direction of acceleration is the same as that of velocity. In this type of motion, acceleration only affects changes of velocity: it causes it to increase or decrease (depending on the sense of the acceleration vector).

If the sense of the acceleration vector →a is the same as the sense of the velocity vector →v, the velocity of the body increases and the motion is referred to as accelerated motion.

￼
If the sense of the acceleration vector →a is opposite to the sense of the velocity vector →v, the velocity of the body decreases and the motion is referred to as decelerated motion. In this case, instead of acceleration, there is deceleration.

￼
The unit of acceleration is ms2. This results from the following formula:

mss=ms1s=ms2

Acceleration in a curvilinear motion

In a curvilinear motion, the direction of the acceleration vector is at a certain angle to the direction of the velocity vector.

￼
In this case, the acceleration vector has two components:

- A component parallel to the velocity vector (tangent to the path and parallel to the direction of motion) — this is a tangent component a|| that corresponds to the change of the value of velocity.

-A component perpendicular to the velocity vector (perpendicular to the direction of motion) — this is a normal component an that corresponds to the change in the direction of the velocity vector. In perpendicular motion, the value of this component is equal to zero.

Average acceleration

Average acceleration of a material point in a set interval of time is the ratio of the increase of the velocity vector Δ→v to the time Δt in which that increase occurred:

→aavg=Δ→vΔt
The direction of the average acceleration vector is the same as the direction of the change of the velocity vector.

￼
At the starting moment, a material point t1=0 moved with the velocity of v1. After some time, at the moment t2=t, its velocity was equal to v2. The change of velocity during the motion is equal to:

Δ→v=→v2−→v1
The time in which the displacement took place is equal to:

Δt=t2−t1=t

Instantaneous acceleration

Instantaneous acceleration is acceleration of a body in an interval of time approaching zero. Instantaneous acceleration is defined as the limit of the quotient of the vector of change of the velocity Δ→v and the time Δt in which the change occurred:

→a=limt→0Δ→vΔt
The direction of the instantaneous acceleration vector is the same as the direction of the change of the velocity vector.

￼
Differential notation:

→a=d→vdt=d2→rdt2

Forget the formula. Here’s a simple way. You are driving 5 m/s/s and you want to know how fast you were at 122m (the time you got pulled over). You know you hit that distance in 7 seconds, so do 5x7 which equals 35. If you do not know how to get the 5 m/s/s, you just simply do algebra. Your initial speed is 0 and in the formula you have to multiply initial speed, a.k.a. velocity, with time. 0(7)=0. Now that you have gotten that out of there, do pemdas. 1/2(acceleration) converts to its opposite to bring it to the other side where 122 is. It is now 122(2)=244. All you have left on the other side is (acceleration)7^2. Do the opposite and Ladda ladda you have 244/7^2. 7^2 is 49 so it is really 244/49. Whip out a calculator or become a try-hard and do it in your brain and you will get 4.9 which rounds to 5. That is how you find acceleration in this particular displacement formula.

Physics likes to give algebraic values to the most simple things.
t- time - how long have you been driving for
v-speed/velocity - how fast were you driving the exact moment
a-acceleration - how fast were you gaining speed
d- distance traveled

v = d/t is nothing more than the formula for average , primary level stuff

In fact this is all very simplistic , because irl nobody drives at a constant speed or with constant acceleration. Calculating averages only gives you vague idea about what happens during the trip. If you don't get this very symbolic physics ... god help you

Motion contains 2 variables, the 2 variables being speed and distance. Variables range from zero to infinity. Thus the most extreme motion would be to travel across an infinite distance at an infinite speed. Crossing an infinite distance means that you will go on forever, since there is no end to an infinite distance.

If it takes time to get from say point A to point B, then you can obviously move faster and move from point A to point B in a shorter time period. Thus if time is required to move from point A to point B, then you are clearly traveling at a finite speed. However, if you move from point A to point B in zero time, then you are clearly traveling at an infinite speed. You can't go faster than this.

So if you travel across an infinite distance at an infinite speed, you will go on forever, in no time at all. Thus it will never end, but it will all be over with in no time at all. Thus we have 2 opposite extremes. This can not occur holistically. Therefore it must be relativistic instead. Further analysis of this leads you to independently discovering Einstein's theory of Special Relativity.

Hi here are some teaching methodology things that could make this easier to understand
(because I had already studied this before watching the video and thought I understood it but could not follow the video at all, despite it not having any new information in it)

-Put the list of things that will be studied at the beginning instead of the end (if you can summarise very briefly what each thing is about that's even better) (compromise: put them in the description) (this is called previewing)
- ASK QUESTIONS all the time, and pause to give people a chance to think (or instruct them to pause the video if it will require more time)
Sometimes one thing logically follows from another, and if you ask people to figure it out not only does it keep them paying attention, it also helps them to remember. That's one type of questioning.
Another type is more obvious, more like a test question, where you give people something similar to do just with different numbers, and say you will give the answer next week (and people can help each other in the comments).
- Explain everything without using math symbols first, then explain it again using maths. You can't use maths to explain things to ordinary people, you just can''t.
- You can speak at any speed as long as you pause occasionally. This even works for people for whom English is not their first language (they just need more pauses). I.e. No jump cuts
-Have concept checking questions at the end of the video for people to answer in the comments. This encourages self-recitation and improves memory as well as allowing students to notice which parts they did not understand.

You are already using visuals, movement, connecting it to things we already know, showing enthusiasm, so this is all good. But otherwise the teaching methodology is very old fashioned and such a difficult subject would especially benefit from modern methods.

If anyone here wants to get interested in physics but for some reason is having trouble, I'd recommend first looking up cool people such as Louis Slotin and Richard Feynman. For gaining actual knowledge, check the physics section at Barnes and Noble. Michio Kaku, Carl Sagan, Kip Thorne, Brian Greene and on are all great authors for beginners. I wouldn't buy any books there since they're a bit pricy, so check a library or amazon. Learning the secrets of the universe is absolutely amazing.

I sorely miss in this episode the historical retrospective approach that is usually present in Crash Courses. I don't know if it was an intentional decision to "just get on with it" and bring up various textbook examples or if it just happened to turn out that way. I'm personally not a big fan of teaching in the form of pure number-crunching, I like to know a thing or two about how things get discovered and developed because that knowledge increases the motivation and appreciation of a subject.

A great start here would for instance have been by tackling the basic question of why motion was so hard to get right by the ancients (and medievals)? Contrasting Aristotle's notion with the early impetus theory by Philoponus would have been a great start and then showing how various medieval Arab and European philosophers more or less successfully tried to improve upon Philoponus' theory until Newton finally got it "right"'. That would have been a great way of combining the history and philosophy of physics with the practice of physics.

I think I just figured out why I didn't learn the physics from school and never got around to remembering all the formulas and understanding the more advanced concepts. I think it is because just like in this video, 85-90% of the content is in the form of uncommon words, uncommon interactions, and unusual names that seem important, take time to remember, and even more to even partially comprehend. So I find myself falling behind the video trying to build a building with materials I have never used and don't really understand that well were they all should fit in the first place. My suggestion for fixing this pacing problem is to have a specialist that has a deep understanding of these things try to teach someone that has no affiliation with the field but is interested and wants, just like us, to understand and see where people stutter in understanding this. I sincerely think there is a fundamental difference between how a professor teaches a class at his courses and how a specialist gives a crash course to one of his friends through simple conversation. I remember a time where these crash course videos were entertaining and teaching at the same time, telling an interesting story I could easily remember and hardly wait to share with my friends and colleagues, but the latest series have been almost no different from the dry and hollow hours in my schools, university, etc. Most might say that it is simply the nature of the subjects, they are inherently boring to teach and learn, but I will refuse to accept that the ideas that describe and help us understand our world are indeed as dull as they are depicted by those who understand them and imagined by the rest of us. I understand that this is, as the name implies, a crash course, were I will be showered with information on a specific subject, but showering us with formulas, definitions, nomenclature and "this is how we physicists do things" rules won't help the people that haven't had and will not have anything to do with physics. Even in the comment section, I see people ranging from specialists discussing some of the things that were wrong or were missed in the video to people that are now starting physics courses, so almost everyone here knows or will know all these things regardless of the existence of these videos, then what is the purpose here if not to help the rest(me included) get to know this field at least a little, not as the current/future wife/husband for better, for worse, in sickness and in health, but as an good acquaintance or even a friend one can be proud to say they know of when this person does something amazing(like they always do) and apear on the science news. I really hope that all this drama and analogies I spewed in this one comment will help in the planning of future videos, I also know that I may be really wrong here, but these were my honest thoughts and feedback and I give them because I think your work is great and important enough that it deserves my time in thinking this up and putting it into words. So just keep it up! :D

Great! Physics show, yay! Also, I have to note something in this video is wrong, and most physics teacher get it really wrong:
Physics is about making best model which fits situation. Velocity or speed is not real, this is something we use to describe reality. There is absolutely nothing real about physics. As a physics teacher I was really hoping this would be a good series. Sadly, so far I'm disappointed. Aside from the errors others have already pointed out, this series is shaping up to have all of the typical flaws of a typical American physics class. It moves too quickly and puts too much emphasis on the mathematical equations. There is little to no discussion of WHY those equations work, which is the only actual physics in this lesson. Everything else is just algebra. As Dr. Somara said in the introduction, physics is about understanding how (and why) the universe works the way it does, so it's distressing to see yet another educational video simply saying "These are the equations you should use" without talking about where they come from or why they work. As another example of this, we are told that time always goes on the x (or independent) axis of the motion graphs, but we're not told why that is. It's left as something you just have to know, rather than something that makes logical and physical sense.

Also, not showing the derivation of the equation at 7:20 was not a good choice. Part of the advantage of an animated video is being able to rearrange equations visually for the audience which is something we can't do on chalk, white, or smart boards in our physical classes. I'm sad to see they're not taking advantage of that.

I suppose this is better than nothing, but I was hoping for something more. Just as long as they don't cover free fall and two-dimensional motion next week...

SUGGESTION FOR CRASH COURSE!

I know you have planned 12 episodes ahead, but I have a suggestion. I have Bachelor in Physics and teach in a high school so I have a bit of knowledge about what I am about to say. Physics is counter intuitive. Very much so. Classical physics is, Modern physics, even more so. I think me and a few other "sciency" people are just lucky to have grasp the intuition early in our life and it makes understanding physics a much easier thing to do. Unfortunately, for most people, it is not so. To learn physics 'typically', learning one concept and and principle at a time, I think, is not the best way to go.

Instead, I am suggesting the "historical" route where one should start with learning Aristotelian physics, which is the most intuitive kind of physics. Aristotelian physics works most of the time, but of course we know it is very inaccurate. Then, we use experiments or thought experiments to proof/show/demonstrate how it actually is wrong, then we will progress slowly to classical physics and then modern physics.

Another rationale for doing this, besides it is easier on the learner's mind, is to teach a more accurate worldview of physics and science. Physics has never been a bunch of laws and counter intuitive concepts that just work which people somehow just know since time memorial. It is basically a description about universe which grows more and more accurate slowly over millenias. It begins from something as "duh!" as, if you throw things up, it will go down. Developing to Aristotelian mechanic, Classical Mechanic, and quite literally, rocket science. But most importantly, the journey has not stop. We know for sure that our description is not perfect because it doesn't match the observed data, but it will continually grow to be more so.

So if it is not too much of a hassle, please put more history, experiments, thought experiments and philosophy. Thank You!

The equation around the 7:30 mark isn't accurate according to my understanding. I've been trying for 20 minutes now to see how I'm wrong but I can't seem to disprove myself. It' shouldn't be average velocity (v̅), it should be velocity at time t (v). It's not just a symbol thing, it's printed on the screen and she says "average velocity", so it's kind of really important. Later in the episode it's corrected as just "final velocity" (v). Math below to support, and a link to further explain (http://physics.info/motion-equations/).

Let's say you start at 6m/s (v0), and constantly accelerate at a rate of 1m/s^2 for a time of 4 seconds. Plug all the numbers in and you get a velocity of 10m/s (because 6+1*4=10m/s). But 10m/s is your final velocity (aka velocity at time t=4s), not your average velocity. You started at 6m/s, ended at 10m/s, so your average was 8m/s. I'm not trying to be picky, but it seems entirely incorrect to say that average velocity is equal to the rest of that equation.
For velocity at time t (aka instantaneous or final velocity), we get v=v0+at
For average velocity, we get v̅=(v1+v2)/2

Again, I'm hoping I overlooked something and I've messed up. Please correct me if I did. But if I'm right, then come on CC get your stuff right. I teach physics and would really, really (pretty please!) like it if you don't use the wrong words, even if/especially if those words have similar meanings yet definitely not the same meaning. It's kind of a big difference. I'll happily tell the officer that my average speed was below the speed limit, but the cop only cares about instantaneous speed.

My father once got a speeding ticket via mail cause he was caught by a speed camera. Thing is, it was a mobile setup to also catch motorcycles that don't have a license plate on the front. so there were two cameras taking two pictures, one from the front with the speed, one from the back with the license plate. unfortunately (for the cops) the date and time was in both pictures but the internal clocks of the cameras werent synchronised. So my father who is a gradutae physicist took out his calculator and calculated that according to the evidence pictures and the distance traveled between the pictures (wich can be measured if you know that a german highway-marking is always 25m long)  he was going veeeery slow. (Something around 1m/second or 2mph in imperial) He was lucky though, cause if the cameras would have been placed the other way around he would have come up with a result that would have indicated that he was going faster than the speed of light. He send all these calculations to the cops and never heard of them again.

First a compliment: You did a better job than I did when I first tried to make a video on this topic (see my FlippedPhysics channel :p).

However, I still think there has to be a way to teach this without it being dense. More jokes and anecdotes, more applicability and inspiration. In the classroom, we have more time, and we can make it more hands-on. It's far harder in video form. The most difficult thing is the time limit, which means this probably needs to be split into a couple of videos. If I recreated my original video on this topic, that's definitely what I would change.

The good thing is that physics gets far easier to make interesting as it moves on to other topics. I'm sure this will get better, just because the material gets so much easier to be passionate about. Anyway, good luck! :)

Hey, +Crashcourse I don't know when we'll get into kinematics graphs, but for me, I always remembered the weird phrase AVID DIVA as the way to remember when to take the area under the graph (AVD) or when to take the slope of the graph (DVA).

So for example, if you have the area graph, you can get the velocity by finding the area under and then take the area under of that new velocity graph to find the displacement. (Working left to right)

The I in each part doesn't actually mean anything, but if you think of an avid diva and like an energetic dancer or prima donna, it can be an interesting way to memorize when to take the slope or the area of the graph.

I'm sorry, but the triangle version (Δ) of the Greek letter delta is uppercase, not lowercase (which is δ, the one somewhat used in calculus, though often shorthanded into the English "d").
For those who do not know why, this is because the uppercase delta stands for any change in value, including big one; lowercase delta is used in calculus to denote infinitesimally small changes in value.
